How do I define a new token using Verus, and what does it mean to set the `proofprotocol` to `PROOF_CHAINID`?

To define a new token using Verus, you can use the `definecurrency` command. The command `./verus -chain=VRSCTEST definecurrency '{"name":"mycoin","options":33, "proofprotocol":2,"currencies":["vrsctest", "gold"],"minpreconversion":[10000,5.1298]}, "initialsupply":20000'` defines a new token named "mycoin".

In this command, several properties are being set for the new token:

* `name`: The name of the token, in this case "mycoin".
* `options`: An integer that can be configured to set various properties of the token, in this case set to 33.
* `proofprotocol`: The protocol used to prove ownership and validate transactions on the token's blockchain. In this case, it is set to 2, which corresponds to `PROOF_CHAINID`.
* `currencies`: An array of currencies that can be converted to the new token, in this case `vrsctest` and `gold`.
* `minpreconversion`: An array specifying the minimum amounts of each currency required to convert to the new token, in this case 10,000 `vrsctest` and 5.1298 `gold`.
* `initialsupply`: The initial supply of the new token, in this case 20,000 units.

Setting the `proofprotocol` to `PROOF_CHAINID` means that the controller of the chain ID has the ability to mint new coins. This can be done using the `sendcurrency` command, for example: `./verus -chain=VRSCTEST sendcurrency "mycoin@" '[{"address":"mike@","currency":"mycoin","mintnew":1,"amount":10000}]'`. This command would mint 10,000 new units of `mycoin` and send them to the address `mike@`.

```
./verus -chain=VRSCTEST definecurrency '{"name":"mycoin","options":33, "proofprotocol":2,"currencies":["vrsctest", "gold"],"minpreconversion":[10000,5.1298]}, "initialsupply":20000'
```
In "mycoin", I set proofprotocol to 2, which is PROOF_CHAINID. That means that the controller of the chain ID can mint new coins as follows:```
./verus -chain=VRSCTEST sendcurrency "mycoin@" '[{"address":"mike@","currency":"mycoin","mintnew":1,"amount":10000}]'
```
